description: Cairn in Devon

name: Snowdon Cairns (Dartmoor)
description: Four cairns on Dartmoor in a rough north/south line, each cairn gets smaller as you go towards the north.  The three southern cairns are spaced 120m apart, the smallest northern one is 175m away and not marked on the OS map.

name: Shell Middens at Westward Ho!
description: Mesolithic shell middens at the south end of Westward Ho! Beach (Mesolithic to Late Neolithic - 8000 BC to 2201 BC (Between)) No evidence remained in 2002.

name: Mardon Down Mortar Pit
description: What looks like a cairn close to the junction of footpaths on the top of Mardon Down is in fact a mortar pit, made by troops based here in the build up to D Day during the second world war.

name: East Lowton settlement
description: Four lovely hut circles, near Fernworthy on Dartmoor. So easy to get to and so rewarding to see, One of them is written on the 1:25000 OS map as a cairn circle, but it's now classed as another hut, which it is.

name: Laughter Tor Longstone
description: A large standing stone stands 2.4 metres tall on the slopes of Laughter Tor, at the head of one double stone row, with remains of a second smaller row nearby.

name: Chinkwell Tor Cairn
description: Cairn in Devon

name: Third Roborough Down Earthworks
description: Misc. Earthwork in Devon

name: Second Roborough Down Earthworks
description: This is a circular earth work approximately 15m diameter. It is located on Roborough Down about 200m ESE of the main Roborough Down Earthwork (see nearby sites on our page), on the Eastern side of the A386. It is a short walk from a nearby car park and the immediately surrounding gorse, bracken and brambles are trimmed by somebody so that it is accessible and visible.

name: Dornafield Tumulus
description:
Round Barrow(s) in Devon.
 A Tumulus and two mounds are marked on the OS map just to the East of Dornafield, an ancient house with a popular caravan park business attached to it.

name: Bellever Tor 10
description: Only one side of this cist remains. It consists of a slab of granite standing upright to a to height of 0.75m. It is 0.8m wide and 0.2m thick and appears to be an end-stone. At its foot is a slab which is partially buried and it was impossible to take its dimensions.

name: Kestor Settlement
description: On the slopes of Kestor, Chagford Comon, are the remains of a large ancient settlement with around twenty-seven hut circles. Apart from the major bronze age remains to be found, evidence of settlement dating back to the Neolithic and even before have been found here. The remains of many huts can be seen, but perhaps more impressive are the associated field systems and boundary walls.

name: Brent Fore Hill

name: Eylesbarrow
description: The remains of two very large oval cairns on the summit of Eylesbarrow. The easternmost, called Eylesbarrow, measures 28m east to west and 26m north to south with a height of 1.8m. The other measures 20m east to west and 22m north to south and is 1.2 m high.

name: Yellowmead
description: Four Concentric Stone Circles in Devon. This site was restored in 1921 and consists of four concentric stone circles, one of which surrounded a cairn, now badly ruined. A stone row runs to the south-west.

This stone row is also a double row, and is located 12m W of the longstone parallel with this row but just 5 pairs of stones barely show above the turf. This is quite clearly a man made structure. The two very large parallel slabs look very much like they are an artificial construction rather than natural. One end has a clearly built up wall to form a structure.

It was prompted by the chance discovery of Roman coins in fields at Ipplepen, near Newton Abbot about five years ago. Archaeologists who have been excavations for several years say it is the first of its kind in the county.

It probably came from somewhere along the lane that we followed from Lustleigh via Higher Combe and Sanduck

description: Stone Row in Devon

name: Crow Tor
description: A kerbed cairn and cist on Dartmoor. The cairn consists of a stony, turf-covered mound, and measures 4.5m in diameter and 0.45m in height. There are traces of a retaining kerb of leaning, granite slabs to the northeast and south. The cist is set slightly to the north of the centre of the cairn.

name: Crownhill Down Cairn Circle
description: At SX57486026 is a cairn Circle set on a high point with distant views in most directions. It lies in very dense gorse in an area of close-cropped moorland turf and comprises an amorphous mound 0.5m high and 6.0m in diameter enclosed by an incomplete ring of boulders.

name: Huntingdon Warren Plane Crash Memorial Cross
Huntingdon Warren Settlement
description: Ancient Village or Settlement in Devon

name: Devil's Stone, Shebbear
description: The Shebbear Devil's stone in Devon is made from a type of quartz not found in the area, measures about six feet by four feet and weighs about a ton. It is a possible remnant of a standing stone and may have been an original foundation stone of Henscott Church.

name: North Morte Well
description: Holy Well in Devon

name: St Helena Volcanic Stone
description: This interesting small memorial stands on a grassy patch near public benches overlooking  Plymouth Sound, below the rather grim, towering, Royal Citadel in Plymouth.

name: Cut Hill Cairn
description: Cairn in Devon

name: East Hill Promontory Fort
description: Promontory Fort in Devon. An Iron Age promontory fort is located on a spur between the East Okement River and the Moor Brook. The western side of the fort (the easiest direction to approach it) is defended by a well-preserved rampart and ditch. Inside the fort there are remains of an earlier enclosure.

name: Kes Tor Rock Basin
description: Natural Stone Feature in Devon

name: Sister's Fountain
description: This elaborate structure was erected over a spring in the 19th century and named Sisters Fountain because the owners nieces liked to play in its vicinity.  The spring is reputed to have gushed forth from a spot where Joseph of Arimathea struck the ground with his staff.

name: Dripping Well (Barnstaple)
description: Holy Well or Sacred Spring in Devon

name: Greystone
description: An impressive standing stone in a prominent position overlooking Woolacombe Bay.  It is possible to park on Sandy Lane at Seymour Villas, and then walk north-west through two small fields, which contained cattle when we visited.

name: Maggie Cross
description: Maggie Cross sometimes known as Postbridge Cross or St Margarets Cross was believed to have stood at a nearby junction as a waymarker for the old trans-moor track, long before the B3212 was built. It is set into a wall opposite St Gabriel's Church, Postbridge.

name: Brisworthy
description: Twenty-four surviving stones of an original forty-two form an attractive and well-ordered circle 24.7m (81 feet) in diameter on Southern Dartmoor. The stones are graded from upward from the south to the north, with the tallest at the north being 1.1m (3 feet 8 inches) high.

name: Ringmoor Down
description: On the open moor of Ringmoor Down, to the north of Brisworthy, a collection of ancient sites are to be found. These include Brisworthy stone circle, Ringmoor Down circle and row, several varied cairns and nearby settlements.

name: Giant's hill cairn
description: This cairn, situated just above the River Plym at 320.0m OD, consists of a mound of turf-covered stones 5.0m in diameter and 0.5m high. In the centre is a 1.0m square depression 0.4m deep.

name: Lower Hartor tor settlement.
description: Ancient Village or Settlement on Dartmoor in Devon

name: Challacombe Cross Settlement

name: Woodbury Castle

name: Upper Erme Cairns
description: Considering all the number of ancient settlements and other signs of habitation in the Erme valley, there are relatively few cairns and other burial monuments to be found. For the entire 3.3 km length of the Upper Erme stone row, just four cairns, three of which are small and inconspicuous, are seemingly related to it, unlike the other great rows of the southern moor, which all have many cairns situated near to them.

Whilst the row has been destroyed, the terminal cairn with a cist and a double circle of stones still remains.

name: Mardon Down N

name: Craze Lowman Mound
description: A prehistoric mound in Devon, possibly a flattened bowl barrow, up to 1m high and 15m in diameter. Cut in half by a road.

name: Archerton Settlement
description: Archerton Settlement is roughly oval in shape. It measures about 110m NNE-SSW by 90m (approximately 0.81 hectares in area) within a broad rubble wall or bank which is denuded and probably extensively robbed.

name: Chittaford Down cairn circle and cist

name: Harbourne Head Standing Stone
description: The Harbourne Head menhir is situated west of the head of the Harbourne stream. It is 2.40m in length and 1.0m by 0.3m at its base tapering to 0.3m by 0.15m.

name: Harbourne Head A
description: Two cairns on the summit of their hill. The North West one is 22.5 metres in diameter with a height of approximately 1.0 metre.

name: Brockhill Settlement
description: Ancient Settlement in Devon

name: Hembury Fort
description: Neolithic Causewayed Enclosure and Iron Age Hillfort in Devon. All above-ground traces of the Causewayed Enclosure seem to have disappeared.

name: Stoke Rivers fort
description: Stoke Rivers [Beara] Camp is located in Devon.

name: Whitehorse Hill cist
description: Small Bronze age cist on Whitehorse Hill, Dartmoor Forest. Discovered in the early 21st century and scheduled in 2003. Due to its remote location it represented a rare example of an undisturbed cist on Dartmoor. It was excavated in August 2011.

name: Trentishoe Settlement and tumuli

name: Friendship Farm Tumuli

name: Delamore House dolmen
description: I came across this modern dolmen by accident when someone told me about Delamore House near Ivybridge. I see they have an open art exhibition there at the moment, if you're looking for somewhere to visit in Devon or Cornwall.

name: Sittaford Stone Circle
description: Dave P writes: A new stone circle has been reported on Dartmoor according to the Devon Archaeological Society Newsletter (Jan 2014 No. 117).  It was discovered by Alan Endacott in 2007 but I have not seen any public mention of it until now.

name: Puddock's Well
description: Angie Lake and friend Peter Green, who instigated the search in Oct. 2010, visited this well on 22nd April 2015 as part of their investigations into the site of a possible major Celtic Sanctuary in the mid-Devon area around the 'nymet' villages.

name: Merrivale Menhir
description: A large Standing Stone making up part of the Merrivale complex on western Dartmoor in Devon. The menhir is 42 metres south of the centre of the stone circle, and is 3.1 metres high. Several other small stones stand in the vicinity, and there are also the remains of several cairns and pits.

name: Shell Top South-West stone row
description: A 73.5m long single stone row including about 30 slabs most of which are fallen. A large recumbent slab at the northern (upper end) probably represents a fallen terminal pillar and a spread mound at the south is likely to be a cairn.

name: Holne Moor
description: Holne Moor Triple Stone Row in Devon, 150 m long. Most of the stones hardly show above the peat.  There is a fallen 3.4m longstone at the Western end.

name: Money Pit cairn
description: This site has often been referred to as a stone circle, but it is in fact the remains of a round barrow with a double retaining kerb circle with diameter of c.3m and interior cist. 2 partially destroyed and badly robbed stone rows descend form the circle at the NNW and the SSE.

name: Merrivale row 4
description: Merrivale single stone row 4, part of the Merrivale complex on western Dartmoor in Devon. A short row of 4 small stones next to the large standing stone. Although close to the menhir the row is clearly not aligned on it.

name: Hart Tor North prehistoric settlement
description: The settlement includes at least 50 round houses, several lengths of rubble walling and at least two cairns.

name: Hart Tor North ring cairn
description: A ring cairn surviving as a partial ring of close-set stones standing up to 0.75m high, surrounding a slightly raised internal area with a diameter of 7.5m.

name: Woolacombe Memorial
description: Modern Standing stone type memorial above the beach at Woolacombe, for the American soldiers of the second World War based in this area.

name: Damage Barton 3
description: Northernmost of three standing stones to the northeast of Mortehoe.

name: Damage Barton 2
description: Second of three standing stones to the northeast of Mortehoe.

name: Whitestone (Lee)
description: Spending a wet New Years afternoon exploring the top left corner of Devon, I noticed on my map some standing stones marked (unknown to me), one of which was near to a small road leading down to a cove at Lee Bay, so I went for a look.

name: Grey Wethers.
description: The walk to this double-ringed circle is long and tedious, but well worth the effort. Excavated in 1898 and restored in 1909, they contained charcoal bits throughout. Attention to detail during construction is obvious in that the circles stand almost exactly north-south of one another.

name: Longstone hill
description: Cairn and fallen standing stone in Devon

name: Fordsland Ledge Chambered cairn
description: Fordsland Ledge Chambered cairn is 12.2m by 13.9m in diameter, in the middle of the cairn are the stones of a ruined chamber.

name: High Willhays kerb cairn
description: Round Cairn in Devon

name: Yes Tor cairns
description: Two cairns at the top of Yes Tor on Dartmoor, the western one is massive and now looks like a huge ring cairn (it's not).

name: Raddick Hill North
description: Raddick Hill North is a Bronze Age enclosed settlement sitting on the southern edge of a tin streamwork scarp. The settlement survives as a sub-circular enclosure with an entrance on its west side.

name: Three Barrows West prehistoric settlement
description: A dense concentration of prehistoric enclosures and round houses on the west facing slopes of the Erme Valley on Dartmoor.

name: Woolhanger henge
description: Henge in Devon

name: Twitchen barrows
description: Two prehistoric round barrows are visible at the east end of the summit of Twitchen Ridge.

name: Two Barrows (Kinsford Gate)
description: Barrow Cemetery in Devon

name: Ackland's Moor
description: Standing Stones in Devon

name: St Leonard's Well (Hartland)
description: St Leonard's Well, Newton Cross, Hartland, Devon. This is on the site of St Leonard's Chapel and there are still remnants of medieval stone windows built into the wall of the old cottage just up from the well.

name: White Hill
description: Bronze Age settlement in Devon

name: Fernworthy
description: This is the overall sitepage for the Fernworthy collection of ceremonial sites. On the eastern upslopes of Dartmoor, just a couple of miles to the southwest of the lovely little old town of Chagford at the upper reaches of the South Teign River, is found the lovely Fernworthy Reservoir within the Fernworthy Forest plantation, now a popular nature reserve and outdoor recreation area. Within this forest at a place known as Froggymead can be found the Fernworthy collection of ancient prehistoric ceremonial sites, which consist of a stone circle, three stone rows or avenues with their associated terminal cairns, plus a few other cairns. Also within this forest can be found several ancient settlements consisting of ancient hut circles and other related structures.

name: White Ridge pound
description: Circular enclosure similar to its larger neighbour a couple of hundred metres to the north, although about half its size. Now identified as a ring cairn.

name: Fernworthy Cairn 4
description: The first monument to look for, which you might otherwise miss is cairn 4, found right at the corner of forest, trackway and open area.

name: Fernworthy Cairn N
description: The cairn at the northern terminus of the northern stone row was until fairly recently covered by the forest, but this has now been cleared. Its not much to look at, but clearly defines the northern end of the row.

name: Fernworthy Cairn SW
description: The northern terminus of the southwestern stone row 3 is a circular cairn about 8 metres in diameter with a surrounding cairn of small stones.

name: Fernworthy Cairn SE
description: The northern terminus of the southeastern stone row 2 is a circular cairn about 8 metres in diameter with a possible surrounding cairn of small stones.

name: East of White Tor Cairn 4
description: Cist in Devon

name: Cairns East of White Tor
description: There is a group of four Cairns to the east of White Tor in the parish of Peter Tavy on Dartmoor, of which three are in very close proximity to each other.

name: Cairns North of Roos Tor
description: There are remains of a couple of cairns on the top of the raise, on the ridgetop about halfway between Roos Tor and Langstone Moor stone circle

name: Meshaw Moor (West)
description: Round Barrow in Devon

name: Black Tor (Meavy)
description: Double Stone Row in Devon. The row measures 950 feet (289.43m) long and terminates at the north-east in a blocking stone. The position of the blocking stone indicates that the row was originally of the double type and that the northern stones have been buried by the adjacent field boundary.

name: Royal Hill Cairns (SX620721)
description: There are several cairns, many with cists still to be seen within them which can be found on the slopes of Royal Hill, to the southeast of Princetown.

name: Soussons Down Cairns
description: Four Bronze Age round barrows between 10 and 20 meters in diameter and 0.5 to 2.2 meters high. One barrow was excavated in 1902, finds included pottery and flints.

name: Hookney Tor Cairn
description: A tor cairn situated on Hookney Tor and forming part of a discrete cluster of mounds running along a prominent ridge. The cairn includes a rubble bank attached to the southern face of a rock outcrop.

name: Birch Tor Cairn
description: The remains of a large, flat-topped cairn lie on the ridge crest 230m N of Birch Tor. The spread, heather-covered mound measures 16m N to S by 18m and a maximum of 1.8m high on the W.

name: Chagford Common Cairn
description: A small round barrow 15 feet diameter by 1.5 feet high, situated

name: Hurston Ridge Settlement
description: The walls of an enclosed hut circle settlement and 3 Hut circles - SX 6733 8249, SX 6736 8251 and SX 6741 8257.

name: Cater Common settlement
description: Ancient Settlement in Devon

name: Royal Hill Cairns (SX621723)
description: There are several cairns, many with cists still to be seen within them which can be found on the slopes of Royal Hill, to the southeast of Princetown.

name: Royal Hill Cairns (SX621724)
description: There are several cairns, many with cists still to be seen within them which can be found on the slopes of Royal Hill, to the southeast of Princetown.

name: Royal Hill Cairns (SX618719)
description: There are several cairns, many with cists still to be seen within them which can be found on the slopes of Royal Hill, to the southeast of Princetown.

name: Combestone Tor
description: Rock Outcrop in Devon

name: Bigbury Tumuli
description: Barrow Cemetery in Devon

name: Bellever Tor 6
description: Jeremy Butler lists ten cairns/kists in the West to South of Bellever Tor. This one is number six in a field by the Cherrybrook River with many other Cairns/kists in the same field. They can be hard to find as the marsh grass is longer then the stones of all these monuments.

name: Bellever Tor Cairn one
description: A nicely formed cairn is found at the edge of the forest with a few surrounding kerbstones and a large capstone covering the remnants of a cist underneath.

name: Money Pit Cairns
description: Two mounds are visible in the vicinity of Grinsell's grid references. That at SX 68147384 is circular, measuring 4.5m. in diameter and 0.7m. high. Adjacent is an elongated mound measuring 11.5m. by 4.4m. and 0.7m. high.

name: Hembury Castle
description: Hembury Castle is a prehistoric hillfort near Buckfastleigh, not to be confused with the better known Hembury near Honiton in Devon.

name: Water hill cairn
description: A cairn on the top of Water hill, really great views.

name: Leather Tor
description: Situated on the southern slopes of Leather Tor, a Cairn and Cist, next to a track off of a minor road at Cross Gate near Burrator Reservoir.

name: Long Stone (East Worlington)
description: A precariously leaning 2.2 metre tall longstone in the parish of East Worlington, near to the village of Witheridge in north Devon

name: Stonehenge at Babbacombe Model Village
description: Babbacombe Model Village in Torquay has a model of Stonehenge which looks pretty accurate, bar the lack of crowds.

name: Ringmoor Down Cairn 4
description: On the open moor of Ringmoor Down, to the north of Brisworthy, several varied cairns can be found. Cairn 4 is marked on the OS map as enclosure, about 100m southwest of the circle of stones, and is likely the remains of a fairly large ring cairn of 35 metres diameter.

name: Ringmoor Down Cairn 1
description: On the open moor of Ringmoor Down, to the north of Brisworthy, several varied cairns can be found. The 10 metre diameter Cairn 1 is about 100m east of Brisworthy stone circle, and was excavated in 1909 with little found.

name: Yellowmead ring cairn
description: Remains of a ring cairn located ~200m from the main circles

name: Ringmoor Down Cairn 2
description: On the open moor of Ringmoor Down, to the north of Brisworthy, several varied cairns can be found. The splendid 5m diameter cairn 2 is to be found about 3 or 400 metres to the northeast of Brisworthy stone circle, but out of sight over the hill.

name: Legis Tor Cairns
description: On the south facing slopes to the east of Legis Tor, uphill from the eastern part of the settlement, can be found the remains of two fairly small cisted cairns about 4 metres in diameter.

name: Trowlesworthy West enclosure
description: On the lower slopes of Trowlesworthy Tor, above the marshes surrounding the Blacka Brook, are fund a couple of stone rows, one single and one double, each with its own cairn and circle of stones at their head.

name: Trowlesworthy Tor settlement
description: On the western slopes of Trowlesworthy Tor, well above the marshes surrounding Blacka Brook are the well spread out remains of a large settlement, consisting of more than half a dozen large enclosures and related hut circles.

name: Legis Tor Enclosures
description: On the southern slopes of Legis Tor, on the northen banks of the River Plym, are the remains of a substantial settlement, consisting of 4 main enclosures with almost 50 hut circles identified either in or between the encolsures.

name: Trowlesworthy Tor north settlement
description: On the north eastern slopes of Trowlesworthy Tor, on the southern banks of the River Plym below Spanish Lake, are the much ruined remains of a settlement.

name: Shadyback Tor settlement
description: To the west of Trowlesworthy Warren farmhouse, on a high spur of land jutting into the river Plym, are the remains of a fairly large settlement, consisting of several enclosed pounds with their hut circles.

name: Bowerman's Nose
description: Rock Outcrop in Devon

name: St Helen's Well (Croyde)
description: On 6th April 2013 I found this holy well tucked down a little side lane serving modern houses.  I knew it was somewhere in Cott Lane, Croyde, having read a news article on the history of the village in the local paper.  Despite growing up in Braunton, about 5 miles away, I hadn't previously heard of it, and I didn't spot it while walking up the lane.

name: Wind Hill
description: The earthwork on Wind Hill overlooks the valley of the East Lyn, with Lynmouth Bay on the north side  a good defensive position.  It is now owned by the National Trust, its eastern rampart a still imposing three metres high.

name: Horn's Cross
description: Horn's Cross stands 2 meters high on Holne Moor.   It can be quite difficult to reach in the summer through the dense bracken and in winter the ground is very boggy, but it is worth the trek as there are amazing views all around.

name: Crazy Well Cross
description: Ancient Cross in Devon

name: Cadover Cross
description: Ancient Cross in Devon

name: Cox Tor Summit Cairns
description: Cairns in Devon

name: Blackslade Down Cairn and Cist
description: This ruined cairn and its reasonably intact cist lies in a shallow valley between Pil Tor and Wittaburrow on Dartmoor.  On the OS map this area is marked as 'Blackslade Down'.

name: Wittaburrow Cairn
description: This cairn high up on Wittaburrow hill is visible from some distance and I'd noticed it while walking to Tunhill Rocks.

name: Top Tor Cairns
description: Cairn in Devon

name: Tunhill Rocks
description: Ancient Village or Settlement in Devon

name: Foales Arrishes
description: Ancient settlement of eight large hut circles in Devon (Dartmoor). This site is actually easier to unravel when viewed from the top of Rippon Tor, to the ESE. When walking along the lower SE contours of the tors - the ridge above Foales Arrishes is fairly level, and Pil Tor is approx SSW of Top Tor - you are met with a jumble of light-coloured stones, and a profusion of bracken.

name: Shovel Down row 2
description: Double Stone Row between SX65958620 to SX65958603, making up part of the Shovel Down complex of sites on eastern Dartmoor

name: Spurrell's Cross
description: Ancient Cross in Devon

name: Smallacombe Rocks Settlement
description:
Smallacombe Rocks Settlement is situated almost due North of the popular Haytor Rocks on Dartmoor.  
The gigantic outcrops of granite that form Haytor Rocks lie near the B3387 from Bovey Tracey to Widecombe in the Moor and are visible from the south east coast at Teignmouth.  It isn't very peaceful, as holidaymakers, and locals alike, regularly visit this stunning scenic area with its panoramic views.

name: Black Hill Cairns
description: Cairn in Devon. Black Hill is a spur at the northern edge of the high ground of Haytor Down, below which the ground falls sharply away to the wooded valley of the River Bovey.  It is outside the land bounded by parallel reaves and may have been reserved for burial monuments as no huts have been found here.

name: Cuckoo Ball Chambered Tomb
description: Chambered Tomb in Devon

name: Butterdon Hill Long Cairn
description: Distinct from the Butterdon Hill Cairns site - this long barrow is on the SE flank of Butterdon Hill, just north of the Cuckoo Ball burial chamber. It is marked on the OS map of Dartmoor, and although it is now little more than a low mound it is not too difficult to find. Walking uphill from Cuckoo Ball chamber it is just beside (to the N of) the third rough track encountered. There are some stones visible but little coherent structure.

name: Holy Well, Ermington
description: Holy Well in Devon

name: Colyton Church Cross
description: Ancient Cross in Devon

name: Chagford Druid's Well
description: This is an odd site whose name is probably Victorian rather than ancient. The spring is enclosed in an unusual 'mini dolmen' structure.

name: Mockham Down Camp
description: Hillfort in Devon

name: Row Barrow (Devon)
description: Round Barrow in Devon

name: Musbury Castle
description: Hillfort in Devon

name: Yellowmead cairn
description: This small Cairn is 38m from the centre of Yellowmead stone Circle. This can be easily missed but is worth hunting out as lt is a very small circle Cairn no more then 2 meters in diameter with five stone still standing.

name: Milber Down Camp
description: Hillfort with stock enclosure in Devon. It consists of three concentric enclosures: the innermost is 116 by 96 metres, the second and third are narrow strips 10 to 25 metres wide, each being defended by a large rampart and ditch.

name: Royal Albert Memorial Museum
description: Exeter and Devon's main museum - The Royal Albert Memorial Museum - set in an imposing old Victorian building in Queen Street, just off the main high street in Exeter's vibrant city centre, is a great place to while away a day and learn more about the history of the county.

name: Kent's Cavern
description: Paleolithic Cave in Devon. Kents Cavern is a cave system in Torquay, Devon, England. It is notable for its archaeological and geological features. The caves are a geological Site of Special Scientific Interest and a Scheduled Ancient Monument, and are open to the public.

name: Seaton Down Camp
description: An Iron Age hill fort consisting of an earthwork with a large linear rampart, it lies at the edge of the north east end of the down on a high promontory, and is approximately 125 metres (410 ft) above sea level.

name: Higher Mattocks Down stone
description: Fallen standing stone, 2.8 metres in length, in Devon

name: Libbett's Well
description: Holy Well or Sacred Spring in Devon. Libbett's Well initially took a bit of finding, but since we now have photos of the route to it, anyone interested can follow these for an easy walk to the site. The well is mentioned in detail in Terry Faull's 'Secrets of the Hidden Source - In Search of Devon's Ancient and Holy Wells'.

name: Vixen Tor
description: Bronze Age cairn and cist. The cairn mound measures 5.5 metres in diameter and stands up to 0.2 metres high. The cist lies within the cairn and survives as a stone lined pit, with its top protruding above the present ground surface.

name: Dumpdon Great Camp
description: An Iron Age hillfort located on a detached hill at the southern end of a steep-sided ridge of Upper Greensand between the River Otter and the Luppitt Brook. The flat topped and triangular shaped hillfort of 2.6 hectares was defended by two substantial ramparts and ditches on the northern side, controlling the only easy line of approach, and by single ramparts on the east and west sides.

name: Doda Well
description: Holy Well or Sacred Spring in Devon. Doda Well at the west end of the small but very picturesque village of Coffinswell is presently nearly overgrown with greenery where it nestles by the roadside. Situated at the west end of the village, it could be an early medieval holy well.  The name is Anglo-Saxon in origin: a personal name.

name: Holemoor Well
description: Holy Well or Sacred Spring in Devon

name: Roundy Park Cairn
description: Situated next to the prehistoric enclosure of Roundy Park, this is one of the largest Cists exposed from its Cairn on Dartmoor.  It lies on the west bank of the East Dart River, about 3/4 of a mile NW of Postbridge, where parking is easily available in the Dartmoor National Park car park (with visitor centre and toilets).  Postbridge's other attraction is its famous clapper bridge.

name: Hound Tor Enclosure
description: Possible Tor Enclosure in Devon

name: Dewerstone
description: Causewayed Enclosure in Devon

name: Denbury
description: Hillfort in Devon. With two close-set ramparts and a deep ditch on the east and south sides, the fort was built around 300-100BC. The Bronze Age barrows inside were there earlier, probably built 1,000 years or more before the fort.

name: West Anstey Barrows
description: There are two prominent round barrows on Anstey Common hilltop, about a hundred metres to the north of the ridge top road, and easily accessible from readily available parking places.

name: Huntsham Castle
description: Misc. Earthwork in Devon

name: Prestonbury Castle
description: Hillfort in Devon

name: Shovel Down Cairn Row 4
description: At the top end of stone row 4 is a 7 metre diameter cairn with a central pit.

name: Cheriton Ridge ring cairn
description: This was a very pleasant surprise, as many cairns on Exmoor are little more than a patch of thicker undergrowth.   Approaching from the north, what looks like a stone (which I assumed must be a sheep) can clearly be seen down by the saddle of the ridge, with some darker heather around it. As approaching nearer to this, and it can be seen that it is indeed a stone, with a few other smaller stones standing nearby.

name: Modern Stone Circle near Kestor Rock
description: Modern Stone Circle in Devon. On private land near Kestor Rock. There is no public access however it is visible from the publicly accessible moor.

name: Moorlands Farm
description: Cairn in Devon

name: Roborough Down Earthworks
description: "The Earthworks" on Roborough Down, near Yelverton, are an archaeological puzzle.

name: Western White Barrow
description: Western White Barrow is a large cairn, 21m by 17.5 m and a maximum of 1.7 m high, and lies on the summit of a broad level hill at 480 m above OD. It has been badly mutilated by the construction of a two room building, with fireplace, 11.5 m by 4.7 m overall, within its mass, and its original form is conjectural. Petre's Cross (SX 66 NE 37) has been set up upon the cairn.

name: Green Hill - Stall Moor
description: This Stone Row is part of the

name: Hoaroak Hill
description: I couldnt find anything of this, in a very swampy area. There is a nice tree and a couple of very active springs here in this delightful place.

name: Cheriton Ridge 6
description: Off the edge of Cheriton Ridge on the western Hoaroak Water side, near to the Hoar Oak itself, can be found the remains of this stone setting.

name: Cheriton Ridge 1
description: Stone Setting reported in my Exmoor Archaeology book, but I found nothing for these.

name: Cheriton Ridge 3
description: Stone Setting reported in my Exmoor Archaeology book, but I found nothing for these.

name: Farley Water stones
description: Standing Stones are marked on the OS map. I looked all around for some standing stones, but could find nothing, except perhaps some stones which were laying flat on the ground, or perhaps a couple of stumps, but there was nothing which obviously shouted standing stone to me.

name: Tottiford Reservoir
description: Stone circle and rows in Devon. Archaeologists have discovered the remains of a prehistoric complex, buried beneath a reservoir in southern England. Archaeologists observing are justifiably astonished at its existence.

name: Brent Tor
description: Hillfort in Devon. Brent Tor is a conical shaped hill rising to a height of 330 metres above sea level. The hill is prominent with in its local landscape and rises steeply about 50 metres from its surrounding landscape.

name: Down Tor cairn
description: About 50 metres to the northwest of the beautiful cairn circle, around the edge of the hillside, is the remains of another cairn, 14 metre diameter and more than a metre high. There are no signs of any kerb stones or structure within the cairn.

name: Narrator Brookhead Enclosure
description: This is an oval shaped enclosure, approximately 50m by 30m which is defined by large stone walls, which nowadays make up a fallen structure about 3 metres wide by up to a metre high. Many upright stones can be seen within the walled structure.

name: Narrator Brookhead Cairn
description: This is a big old cairn which lies in line with the Down Tor stone row, about 150 metres distant from its eastern end. The cairn is about 20 metres in diameter, and up to 2 metres high. It is mostly a pile of clear granite stones, but in places it looks like there may be some structure to parts of it.

name: Holne Ridge NE
description: A couple of hundred metres west from Horn's Cross, can be found Holne Ridge cairn 2 and its supposed double stone row. I didnt think I was going to be able to find this as the area its in is all covered by fern and bracken, but it was quite obvious once I got near. The cairn is well formed, about 7 metres in diameter about a metre tall with the expected hollow in the top.

name: Holne Ridge 7
description: Several cairns of various types and sizes are to be found on the slopes of Holne Ridge, near to Horn's Cross above the O Brook valley south of Dartmeet. Eleven cairns are recorded in Butler Vol 4, but I shall describe here only those which I have seen. I have given the position for cairn 7, which is easy to find being nearest to Horn's Cross, and approximately in the middle of the group.

name: Castle Dyke (Devon)
description: Ancient Village or Settlement in Devon

name: Bush Down Settlement
description: Ancient Settlement in Devon. A superb set of Hut Circles, Rows and Cysts near Lettaford.

name: High Moorland Visitor Centre
description: The High Moorland Visitor Centre (now renamed the National Park Visitor Centre, Princetown) is an ideal place to start your visit to Dartmoor.  There is FREE admission to the Centre, where you will find extensive, modern, interpretative displays that provide wonderful insights to Dartmoor, its history, culture and wildlife, as well as a gallery with regularly changing exhibitions and a small auditorium where visitors are able to watch various short films about Dartmoor. There is also a prehistoric cist in the garden.

name: Whitewell Woods Well
description: Holy Well in Devon. This beautiful Well was built c.1360 by monks on the instruction of the Bishop John de Grandisson of Exeter Cathedral. It was not strictly a Holy Well, but supplied water to the Farm that supported the Bishop's Summer Palace in Bishopsteignton. One purpose was to provide for fish ponds!

name: Furzehill Common 5
description: This excellent stone setting is to be found well off of the steep eastern slopes of Furzehill Common ridge, overlooking the splendid Hoaroak Water valley, with fantastic views. I almost didnt come and look for this one as time was getting on, the hillside was in shadow, and when I got near, I saw that the hillside was covered in ferns. I am glad to say that I did go for a quick look, and eventually found the best stone setting I had seen all day.

name: Stidwell
description: Holy Well or Sacred Spring in Devon

name: Ten Commandments Stone
description: Natural Stone / Erratic / Other Natural Feature in Devon

name: Down Tor circle
description: This has to be one of the most attractive megalithic features on Dartmoor. It is a ring-cairn attached to a 349m (1145-foot) stone row that is concave as it dips downward and then rises upward with the terrain as it approaches the circle. The ruined cairn within the 11m (36-foot) diameter ring is some 8.5m (28 feet) across. There are twenty-five small stones forming the circle, averaging 0.5m (1 foot 7 inches) in height.

name: Grimspound
description: The best known and most easily accessible ancient settlement on Dartmoor. Grimspound is a late Bronze Age settlement, in an excellent state of preservation. The name was first recorded by the Reverend Richard Polwhele in 1797 - it was probably derived from the Anglo Saxon god of war, Grim (more commonly known as Woden, or Odin).

name: Furzehill Common cairn
description: Near to the top of Furzehill Common ridge are the remains of a cairn near to many stones which may once have formed a stone setting.

name: Furzehill Common 2
description: Supposedly a stone setting of three stones in a row, two are marked on the OS map. I found one stone standing just over a foot high surrounded by couch grass. With a good hunt around, I found only one other stump of a stone nearby.

name: Furzehill Common 0
description: Having crossed to Furzehill Common from Warcombe, I found the nearby tumulus easily, and was initially fooled by a small stone standing nearby. However, a bit further up the slopes at the correct position is a decent stone, 2.5 to 3 feet tall standing proud.

name: Warcombe Water stone
description: On the promontory of dry, higher ground leading down from The Chains to Warcombe Water can be found a standing stone, about 2.5 by 1 foot in dimension.

name: Ilkerton Ridge stones
description: I initially found a single stone standing, about three feet tall, but in a hollow amongst the dense heather, a few hundred metres south of the two obvious barrows.

name: Ilkerton Ridge Barrows
description: Several barrows and cairns are to be found on the crest of Ilkerton Ridge, one or two quite large and in very good condition, some of them very small and deteriorated.

name: Furzehill Common Barrow
description: On the western slopes of Furzehill Common, having crossed from Warcombe, I found this tumulus easily, which is fairly large and prominent on the slopes down the side of the ridge.

name: St Boniface's Well (Crediton)
description: Holy Well or Sacred Spring in Devon

name: Archerton Newtake Cist
description: This large granite stone sits in a field to the southwest of the track leading NW up the East Dart River valley from Postbridge (on the river's west bank).  It is in one of the first sloping fields on the left and unmissable.  The far side (NW edge) of the field is bordered by trees.  (Coming back down the valley towards the main road, in the first view of it on your right, it appears to lie on the brow of the hill.)

name: Broadun Settlement
description: Ancient Settlement in Devon. This huge walled enclosure lies on the south east facing slope of Broad Down, commanding excellent views down the valley of the East Dart River towards Postbridge.  As you walk up the river valley towards it the hill dominates the view ahead.  The site isn't easy to pick out because it is so large.  Several ruined hut circles remain.

name: Broadun Ring
description: If you've read the notes on Broadun settlement's site page you'll know that Broadun Ring is just a bit further to the North around the same contour of Broad Down hill, overlooking the valley of the East Dart River, which heads north to south just there, before swinging towards SE as it passes Roundy Park.

name: Siward's Cross
description: Ancient Cross in Devon.

name: Ladywell (Pilton)
description: Holy Well or Sacred Spring in Devon.

name: Cut Hill Stone Row
description: Stone Row in Devon. Cut Hill, 603m high, is no ordinary hill, being one of only five Dartmoor points above 600m in altitude. To reach it requires a walk of about two hours from whatever direction. The hill has no rocky outcrops breaking its surface, but has a smooth domed shape. It is impressive and powerful, especially when approaching from the east, up the East Dart River. Its western flanks form the watershed of the River Tavy.

name: Nether Exe Cursus
description: Cruciform Long Enclosure in Devon

name: Buttern Hill settlement
description: The slopes of Buttern Hill are covered in the remains of ancient settlement, with many reaves and hut circles to be found dotted all over the hillside, particularly the north eastern slopes which seem to be the centre of the settlement.

name: Scorhill Cairn and Rows
description: One or two hundred metres south of Scorhill stone circle, below the leat, can be found the remains of a cairn, with remnants of a double stone row running downhill from it towards the river Teign.

name: Newton Abbot Museum
description: Newton Abbot Museum is situated in the centre of the town with some limited parking close by.  (Several other car parks in town centre.) There are steps leading to the entrance, but according to the website there is disabled access, toilets and a small shop.

name: Lakehead Hill Cairn 8
description: Taking Butlers reference number for this cist (cairn) between Lakehead Hill and Bellever Tor - as he groups it with 'Cairns and Stone Rows on Lakehead Hill' - it is posted here as 'Lakehead Hill Cairn 8'.

name: Lakehead Hill South Hut Circle
description: We visited this hut circle in September 2009.  It is just north of the 'Lichway' on the green and white map 'Prehistoric Features on Lakehead Hill' on this website:

name: Lakehead Hill 6
description: One of two adjacent cairn circles,

name: Bellever Tor N Settlement
description: This settlement lies on the northern slopes of Bellever Tor, and is described as a 'rosette' type of development by Butler in his 'Dartmoor Atlas of Antiquities' [Vol.2 - The North].

name: Lowton Brook West Settlement
description: Ancient Village or Settlement in Devon

name: Hound Tor Ring Cairn
description: Hound Tor Ring Cairn, Dartmoor, Devon, is a ring cairn (Cairn Circle) 6.5 metres in diameter with an outer incomplete set of granite kerb stones. In the center of the cairn is a cist.

name: Whiteworks Cairn Circle
description: A Cairn Circle on an east facing moorland slope close to Whiteworks and Foxtor Mires, c.6 metres diameter and 0.6 metres high surrounded by upright slabs.

name: Bampfylde Hill Barrows
description: Barrow Cemetery in Devon. Angie Lake writes: On a visit to

name: Langridge Wood Cist
description: Cist in Devon. This Bronze Age cist is one of only seven to have been documented on Exmoor, only two of which survive.

name: Furzehill Common Standing Stone
description: This stone was until recently standing about 30 inches tall, but is now broken and laying sadly on the ground near some modern fencing and field boundaries. It is situated at the northeastern edge of Furzehill Common, above the very deep, steep sided Hoaroak Water valley.

name: Bellever Tor NE Settlement
description: Ancient Settlement in Devon. The nearest proper road is a couple of miles away. The toilet is an energetic yomp down a steep slope and through the conifers. When it rains  and here on Dartmoor it really does pelt down  the only shelter is project supervisor Simon Hughes's old VW Golf. "It's started to smell like a dead dog," he says with a big grin.

name: Sidmouth Museum
description: Museum in Devon

name: Harford settlement
description: Remains of an ancient settlement on Harford moor, southern Dartmoor. Many hut circles are to be found, several of them in a very good state of preservation.

name: Watchet Hill Cairn
description: Bronze Age cairn on the summit of Watchet Hill, oval mound is  0.8 metres high and measures 16.6 metres by 13.8 metres.

name: Sittaford Tor pound
description: This enigmatic monument consists of an oval shaped enclosure, about 50 metres east west by 40 metres north to south, defined by embanked rubble walls, up to a metre high and spread to a couple of metres in width.

name: Datuidoc's Stone
description: Early Christian Sculptured Stone in Devon

name: Yar Tor Prehistoric Homestead
description: This intriguing ruin lies just to the right of the road going down the very steep Dartmeet Hill below the summit of Yar Tor, when travelling towards Dartmeet from Poundsgate.  It is easier to see when the bracken dies down, but some of the remaining stones are quite prominent all year round.  There is a handy layby on the left of the road going downhill, which is easy enough to pull out of later (ample views of oncoming traffic on this very steep gradient.)  Then all you need to do is cross over and take a short walk across fairly even ground to the site.

name: Corndon Down Cairns
description: There are four cairns on Corndon Down.  I visited these to photograph them for the Megalithic Portal on Sunday 3rd May 2009, and on this late Spring afternoon, with the sun shining and a strong breeze blowing, it was really a 'superb' ambience, but this might not be so in bad weather!<

name: Merrivale Stone Slabs 1 and 2
description: Stone Row / Alignment in Devon

name: Ringmoor Down Cairn 3
description: High on Ringmoor are several very worn cairns and this kerbed stone cairn. It has probably been added to but it is a nice find on the featureless moorland.

name: Soussons Common
description: Often referred to as a stone circle, the circle of twenty-two surviving stones are actually the kerb of a round cairn, now destroyed.  In the centre lies a badly damaged burial cist.

name: Cosdon Hill cairn 9
description: This cairn on the north western slopes of Cosdon Hill is marked on the DEFRA Magic Map, and it has been suggested that perhaps I had found this when I thought I had found a stone circle. So, the first thing to do is to find and identify this cairn.

name: Sticklepath stone circle
description: Sticklepath stone circle was once well known on the northern slopes of Cosdon Hill, to the south of the village of Sticklepath. The stones were said to dance to the sound of South Tawton church bells.

name: Dolbury Hillfort
description: Dolbury Hillfort sits on a volcanic hill overlooking the National Trust property of Killerton House. Occupied 400BC-43AD.

name: Headless Cross (Moretonhampstead)
description: Modern Stone Circle / Monolith in Devon

name: The Giant's Grave Mardon Down
description: A 20 metre diameter cairn at the summit of Mardon Down in Devon

name: Mardon Down Ring Cairn
description: Ring Cairn on the summit ridge of Mardon Down in Devon.

name: Mardon Down Cairn 1
description: Just south of Mardon Down stone circle is what at first looks like a pile of large stones, but upon investigation is the remains of a cairn with much of the remains of a circle of surrounding stones, and with four large blocks at its southern side, and a large slab just on the outside, probably once the capstone to an internal cist.

name: Mardon Down Cairn 3
description: Just south of the Giant's Grave at the top of Mardon Down, is a smaller but much clearer cairn, about 10m diameter and still with some semblance of a retaining circle of stones.

name: Hillsborough
description: Hillfort in Devon

name: Lade Hill Brook Beehive Hut
description: This beehive hut is situated beside Lade Hill Brook, which runs into the East Dart river just near a very sharp hairpin bend in its flow south. It is mentioned in Butlers 'Dartmoor Atlas of Antiquities, Vol.2 - The North'.  He shows a photograph of it next to map 34 in this series.

name: Berry Castle (Devon)
description: Berry Castle is a very small hillfort, almost rectangular in shape. All that remains is a shallow ditch and rampart in the middle of a cow field.

name: Witheridge Moor Barrows
description: There are three barrows on Witheridge Moor. The moorland was occupied in the bronze age. There are reports that there are several fallen standing stones situated near the eastern most barrow.

name: Whittenknowles Rocks
description: To the west of the Drizzlecombe sites, on a southern facing hillside, can be found the remains of the very large Whittenknowles Rocks ancient settlement.

name: Gutter Tor north
description: On the northern slopes of Gutter Tor can be found several cairns, some with cists within them, in various states of repair.

name: Seven Lords' Lands
description: Cairn-circle in Devon. Circle diameter: 33 feet. Shown as a cairn on the OS Map, this well-preserved cairn is easily accessible from the nearby road. It is disguised by the surrounding gorse and bracken, but only six stones are missing from the close-set kerb of stones. A field wall curves slightly in order to avoid the cairn.

name: Marwell St. Mary's Well
description: Holy Well or Sacred Spring in Devon

name: Hatherleigh St. John's Well
description: This is a delightful brick well house with a wooden door found across the common. The well was used by Tavistock abbey, but no properties are noted for it.

name: St. Rumon's well
description: Holy Well or Sacred Spring in Devon

name: St. Urith's well
description: Holy Well in Devon. Possibly the most interesting of sites as it is associated with the 6th century Celtic Saint Urith who was martyred when the villages cut her head off with a scythe! Her shrine was in the church but lost at the reformation.

name: Holy Well (Tawstock)
description: Holy Well in Devon. One of the best and certainly largest holy wells in the county. I knew nothing of it when I looked for it and was surprised by the size!

name: Warcombe Water row
description: Stone Row on Exmoor. During spring 2006 burning of heather moorland near Ilkerton Ridge revealed a long line of standing stones stretching for some 70 metres. The row was discovered by Celia Haddon, a long time Megalithic Portal contributor. She reported the site to the Exmoor National Park archaeologist.

name: Trout Hill 4
description: Standing Stones in Devon. During 2006 a previously unrecorded stone setting was identified on Trout Hill. The site lies in an area already rich in stone settings, and was surveyed during 2007 by staff of the Universities of Leicester and Bristol. Stone settings are assumed to date from the Late Neolithic or Early Bronze Age (around 4500-3500 years ago) and seem to be unique to

name: Chapman Barrows Quincunx
description: Hoping to find my first complete and unadulterated Exmoor Quincunx (a setting of 5 stones arranged as a square with one in the middle, rather like the spots on the five side of a dice), this was the aim for my day out on the moor, and had entailed a 6.9 km walk across very boggy and marshy moorland to get to it.

name: Woodbarrow (Exmoor)
description: This is another large round barrow high up on Exmoor which is still in a good condition, although a very well used trackway runs past it just to its eastern side.

name: Longstone Barrow
description: This large round barrow is still in a very fine condition, with the ditch around it almost like a moat and full of water on a damp March day. As usual it has been dug into from the top, and this is a big pond today. It is one of the larger barrows on Exmoor, measuring about 30 metres diameter and nearly 3 metres high.

name: Chapman Down Barrow
description: There is a large round barrow on the southeastern slopes of  Chapman Down, which has a large slice cut through to the middle, rather than the usual hole in the top. Other than that, it is still in a very fine condition, with remains of a ditch around.

name: Shobrooke Holy Well
description: Shobrooke Holy Well in Devon

name: Jacob's Well (Jacobstow)
description: This well is found just over a stile in an area of marshy ground. The holy well is very overgrown but was believed to be one of a series of ancient sites adopted by pilgrims on the road to the shrine of St. James of Compostella.

name: Drizzlecombe Cist 6
description: About halfway between the cairn at the top of stone row 1, and the massive Giants Basin cairn can be seen what at first looks like a little pile of large stones. Closer inspection shows this to be a collapsed cist, but with no signs of a surrounding cairn.

name: Drizzlecombe menhir 3
description: Terminal longstone at the southwestern (downhill) end of the Drizzlecombe stone row 3, and as for row 1, the stone is in line with the row, and not a blocker across it.

name: Drizzlecombe menhir 1
description: Part of the magnificent Drizzlecombe complex of southwest Dartmoor, this is a fantastic 3+ metre tall triangular shaped slab standing erect at the downhill end of the Drizzlecombe stone row A, which runs away uphill towards the northeast from it.

name: Belstone Common Cairns
description: Cairn in Devon

name: Rippon Tor
description: Cairn in Devon

name: White Tor (Peter Tavy)
description: White Tor in the Parish of Peter Tavy is a very conspicuous hill on the western edge of Dartmoor, and slopes quite steeply on all sides. The top of the hill has a double concentric oval stone wall fortified structure, and many cairns, huts and other structures within it.

name: Langstone Moor stone row
description: Running off to the north from the Langstone is the remains of a stone row, which can be followed for about 100 metres before it runs out, but there is nothing to suggest that this was the original end.

name: Bow Henge
description: Bow Henge was discovered as crop-marks by the present Devon County Archaeologist Frances Griffith in 1984 whilst flying over Devon with Dickie Dougan (now deceased) as a part of an aerial archaeology exercise.

name: Ugborough Parish Church Prehistoric Earthwork
description: Ancient Village or Settlement in Devon

name: Ugborough Beacon Cairns
description: Cairn in Devon

name: Shaugh Moor Cairns
description: On the moorland near to the Shaugh Moor Stone Row, in amongst the waste tips from the china clay works, are several cairns to be found, many in very poor condition.

name: Shaugh Moor Settlement
description: Several hut circles in various states of repair can be found just uphill from the Shaugh Moor stone row and cairn, one being very close to the cairn circle. At one place, there is a row of three fairly complete circles. A bit further uphill, there is one very good and almost complete hut circle, with evidence of an internal partition wall.

name: Sourton Green Saxon Cross
description: One and three quarter metre tall stone cross shaft standing on the village green opposite the bizarre Highwayman Inn. The granite stone has been identified as an early Christian, Saxon relic, and it has Os and Xs engraved onto two of its faces.

name: Roos Tor north west
description: Here on the western facing slopes of Roos Tor above Godsworthy are the remains of one of Dartmoors largest ancient settlements, with more than seventy huts to be found.

name: Cox Tor north east
description: Here are the remains of an ancient settlement, on the northeast facing slopes of Cox Tor above Godsworthy. The settlement consists of five enclosures and about 25 huts, which are largely in a fairly poor state of repair after the tinners have had their way, and with stone being taken for construction of the nearby farms and field walls.

name: Langstone Moor settlement
description: Here are the remains of a large ancient settlement, on the south facing slopes of Langstone moor above the Walkham valley. The settlement consists of at least seven enclosures and more than 50 huts, which are largely in a fairly good state of repair. This settlement had incomplete excavations here by the Dartmoor Exploration Committee in 1894, which were curtailed early due to bad weather.

name: Langstone Moor row 2
description: Running roughly parallel to the Langstone Moor stone row, less than 100 metres to the west, is an embanked structure, which is possibly an ancient reave, a boundary work, or outer defence for the White Tor fort. On the western side of this embankment runs a very regular line of evenly spaced slabs, which was possibly once another stone row, which was incorporated into the later structure. It is not certain.

name: The Langstone
description: This is a lovely menhir nearly 3 metres tall, standing beside the Lich Way on open ground in a saddle between the many local highpoints of the moor. It was re-erected from a fallen position in its original socket hole, in 1893 by the Dartmoor Exploration Committee.

name: Langstone Moor circle
description: What a lovely circle this must have been before it was largely destroyed as target practice during World War 2. It is superbly situated on a flattish bit of land high above the Walkham valley, seemingly equidistant from the three great tors overlooking the site, these being Great Mis Tor, Roos Tor and White Tor.

name: Belstone Ring Cross
description: The Belstone Ring Cross stands on a granite plinth inside the parish church at Belstone village on the north slopes of Dartmoor.  At eye-level, on the wall beside it, is a board with an account of its history and a helpful diagram to enable the viewer to distinguish the shape of the original carvings.

name: Torquay Museum
description: Museum in Devon.  Their archaeology gallery covers the prehistory of the local area including Kents Cavern

name: Hoccombe Hill (E)
description: In the deepest depths of Exmoor, several kilometres to the northeast of Brendon Two Gates, can be found the remains of this stone setting. It is well down the valleyside, on a sort of diagonal flatter bit, to the south of the main trackway along Hoccombe Hill.

name: Aylesbeare Common tumulus
description: Round barrow in Devon

name: Cadbury Castle (Devon)
description: Hillfort in Devon. Cadbury Castle is an early Iron Age earthwork Fort. Approximately 830ft (250m) above sea-level with views over the Exe valley.

name: No Mans Chapel tumulus
description: Barrow Cemetery in Devon

name: Brendon Two Gates (W)
description: Out on the open moorland to the north of Brendon Two Gates, and to the east of the road, can be found the remains of this stone setting. What I found (March 2007) was three stones in a row, roughly in a NW to SE direction, with the stones each set about 7 metres apart.

name: Sidbury Castle
description: Sidbury Castle is a substantial Iron Age Hill fort near Sidbury in Devon. It occupies a large hilltop overlooking the town and the River Sid at approx 185 Metres above Sea Level.

name: Drizzlecombe cairn 1.
description: This cairn is at the upper end of Drizzlecombe stone row 1 (or A), and is about 7 metres in diameter, and 0.7 metres in height. As usual, it has been dug into at the middle.

name: Drizzlecombe cist 21
description: A bit further up the Drizzlecombe valley from the main sites, on the eastern side of the stream, can be found cist 21.

name: Drizzlecombe cist 22
description: To the south of the main Drizzlecombe sites can be found this cairn with cist. There is not much of the cairn surviving, but a good cist exists, standing proud of the ground.

name: Drizzlecombe cairn 14
description: Kerbed cairn ring making up part of the Drizzlecombe complex on southwestern Dartmoor in Devon.

name: Drizzlecombe menhir 2
description: This is a splendid 4.2 metre tall stone standing up and across the downhill end of the Drizzlecombe stone row C, as a blocker. The stone row runs away uphill towards the northeast from it to its cairn at the top.

name: Drizzlecombe stone 4
description: This stone slab is to be found a hundred metres or so across the Drizzlecombe moorland to the northwest of menhir 1. It stands just over a metre tall, 0.6 m wide and 0.2 m thick.

name: Hamel Down Cairn and Cist
description: Cairn in Devon

name: Hameldown Beacon cairn
description: Barrow Cemetery in Devon

name: Hamel Down Concave cairn (Saucer cairn)
description: Barrow Cemetery in Devon

name: Blackaton Down north cairn (Hamel Down)
description: Barrow Cemetery in Devon

name: Two Barrows (Hamel Down)
description: Barrow Cemetery in Devon

name: Single Barrow (Hamel Down)
description: Barrow Cemetery in Devon

name: Broad Barrow (Hamel Down)
description: Barrow Cemetery in Devon

name: Hamel Down Cross
description: Ancient Cross in Devon

name: Hamel Down Platform Cairn (North)
description: Cairn in Devon

name: Clannon Ball
description: Out on the very blowy moorland to the northwest of Brendon Two Gates, on the slopes above the upper Farley water valley, can be found the remains of this stone setting. I found three stones in a pretty regular triangle shape, but there was possibly once many more stones to be found here.

name: Pig Hill (S)
description: The southern Pig Hill Stone Setting is a nice Exmoor stone setting to visit, although it is not that easy to find. It is on a west facing slope above Farley Water, about 400 metres west of the B.3223 road.

name: Pig Hill (N)
description: Despite being very close to the B.3223 road north of Brendon Two Gates, I found this stone setting very hard to find due to heather and bracken covering the stones.

name: West Anstey Long Stone
description: Despite being just a couple of hundred metres to the north of the ridge top road, and easily reached along bridleways from a good parking area, this stone is not the easiest to find, as it cannot be seen from the road, or indeed from anywhere to the south until you are quite close, as it lies well below the ridge top.

name: St Nectan's Well (Welcombe)
description: Holy Well or Sacred Spring in Devon

name: Thornworthy Cairn
description: Cairn in Devon

name: Fitz's Well
description: Holy Well or Sacred Spring in Devon

name: Fice's Well
description: Holy Well or Sacred Spring in Devon

name: Stalldon Row
description: This magnificent stone row stretches for over 500 metres in a north to south direction, mostly up the southern slopes of Stalldon Barrow hill, but with its northerly end just over the top of hill, and starting to wander back down the northern hillside.

name: St Clare's Well
description: Holy Well or Sacred Spring in Devon.

name: St Gudula's Well
description: Holy Well or Sacred Spring in Devon.

name: St Peter's Well (Bradworthy)
description: Holy Well or Sacred Spring in Devon.

name: Holy Well (Broadclyst)
description: Holy Well or Sacred Spring in Devon.

name: Coverney Well
description: Holy Well or Sacred Spring in Devon.

name: Holy Well (Belstone)
description: Holy Well or Sacred Spring in Devon

name: Ladywell (Abbotskerswell)
description: Holy Well or Sacred Spring in Devon

name: Lady Well (Sticklepath)
description: This well is located beside the old A30 road at the western edge of Sticklepath village. It is very close to a turnoff to the hamlet of Skaigh.

name: St Mary's Well (Bovey Tracey)
description: Holy Well or Sacred Spring in Devon.

name: Childes Tomb
description: To the north of Fox Tor, and on the southern edge of the legendary Foxtor Mire can be found the remains of Childes Tomb, named after the legend of Childe the Hunter, who supposedly froze to death here in a snowstorm in the 12th century. The hunter had left his considerable lands to whoever found and recovered his body for a proper burial, and the monks of Tavistock completed this task and built the cross on top of the ancient grave as a memorial to him.

name: Upper Erme Row
description: This is the longest ancient stone row in Britain, and possibly the world, at just over 3.3 kilometres in length, stretching from the Kiss-in-the-Ring stone circle at the south, northwards along the upper Erme valley and up to a cairn near the top of Green Hill at the north. The southern end is at position SX63526446, the north end at SX63666779.

name: Stall Moor circle
description: At the southern end of the longest ancient stone row in Britain, and possibly the world, can be found the Kiss-in-the-Ring stone circle, miles away from any modern habitation, and a long desolate walk from anywhere.

name: Ranny Brookhead Cist
description: The Ranny Brookhead cist is in the middle of a featureless bit of moor near the bottom of the dip between Stall Moor and Stalldown Barrow, in amongst the damp ground surrounding the Ranny Brook.

name: Royal Hill Cairns
description: There are several cairns, many with cists still to be seen within them which can be found on the slopes of Royal Hill, to the southeast of Princetown. Perhaps the best preserved is cairn 3 at SX620721 which has an almost complete kerb circle, but I did not visit that cairn on my visit.

name: Crock of Gold
description: The Crock of Gold is a fine cairn and cist which can be found just to the south of the track which runs east from Princetown as part of the Dartmoor way, and is named no doubt after a lucky find here by somebody in the past.

name: Erme Pound
description: This is an excellently preserved ancient village on the eastern flanks of the upper Erme valley, one of the largest on Dartmoor, with superb walls around the outside, with at least one entry into it, from near the stream at the north.

name: Hook Lake Settlement
description: Well preserved ancient settlement on the eastern flanks of the Erme valley, consisting of two large walled enclosures, the one to the north a circular shape, with a sort of triangular one to the south. Each enclosure contains several huts.

name: Blatchford Brook Foot Settlement
description: Well preserved ancient settlement on the eastern flanks of the Erme valley, on a bend in the river where the Blatchford Brook joins from the west.

name: Dry Lake North Settlement
description: Fairly well preserved ancient settlement on the eastern flanks of the Erme valley, consisting of several large walled enclosures, each containing several huts.

name: The Heath Stone
description: The Heath Stone can be found not far from the road on the way to Fernworthy Reservoir, on the open moor just before you get to the forest.

name: Grims Grave
description: What a lovely find Grims Grave is, miles from anywhere across the middle of Southern Dartmoor, and well worth a visit.

name: Langcombe Brook 4
description: Several cairns and kists, and some remains of ancient settlement are to be found along the Langcombe Brook, which feeds into the river Plym just above the Drizzlecombe complex. Many of these can be found fairly easily along the sides of the brook, but its a long walk from anywhere in remote southern Dartmoor.

name: Blackbury Camp
description: Hillfort in Devon

name: The Tolmen Stone (Dartmoor)
description: The Tolmen Stone is a large boulder that lies near to the bank of the North Teign river. It has a large hole that perforates through the rock and was formed by river friction erosion. The hole is large enough for a normal sized adult to pass through and is estimated to have a diameter of 1.03m. There are also three other partially worn basins on the boulder.

name: Burridge Ancient Settlement
description: Ancient Village or Settlement in Devon. This is an ancient settlement or camp, not to be confused with Burridge Camp near Banstable, Devon. Presumably pre-Roman, it is ringed by still-substantial double banks and a ditch forming a central area about 500 metres accross. There are what appear to be entrances on the Western and Eastern sides.

name: Saxon Well
description: Holy Well or Sacred Spring in Devon

name: Kraps Ring
description: Located in an open area within the Bellever Plantation on the north facing slope of Lakehead Hill, lies this rather unfortunatly named Bronze Age enclosure. Surrounded by a wall up to 2m in width and probably originally 1m in height, the settlement is c 60m diameter and contains the remains of at least 11 huts (though a plan of 1891 indicates up to 15 huts). Interestingly the remains of a much larger hut (6m diameter), lies outside the settlement, some 35m uphill to the southwest.

name: Lakehead Hill Cairn 7
description: Cairn in Devon. This now heavilly disturbed cairn lies within a small clearing in the Bellever Plantation, not far from the forest track. The cairn measures c. 20m diameter, though the disturbance has spread much of the original material. Two sides of a large central cist have been exposed, and the tops of a number of earthfast stones around the northern edge maybe all that remains of an outer ring.

name: St. Brannoc's Holy Well (Braunton)
description: Holy Well or Sacred Spring in Devon

name: Yar Tor Summit
description: Cairn on Dartmoor, Devon. A cairn, c.18m in diameter, built over the highest rocks of the Tor. Its stones have been arranged to form an elaborate shelter. The cairn's pre-historicity may be doubtful. It may be a modern construction built for shelter purposes.

name: Ouldsbroom Cross
description: Ancient Cross in Devon. Both William Crossing and Harry Starkey refer to this cross as 'Ouldsbroom Cross', though it often takes its name from a nearby house called 'Ollsbrim' on the Ordnance Survey map.

name: Sherwell Long Barrow
description: This long barrow lies on a NW - SE axis, on private land in the hamlet of Sherwell (as spelled on my Ordnance Survey map (Outdoor Leisure 28 Dartmoor).  The hamlet has also been referred to as Sherrill.  The settlement is worth a visit just to see the quaint ancient houses, but I don't think you would be able to access the barrow without permission, and it was nearly 5 years ago that I visited with another member of our local dowsing group, following an invite from the lady owner.  This privacy would be respected by anyone reading this article, I hope.

name: Dunnabridge Pound
description: Dunnabridge Pound is situated almost dead centre of the wild moorland area of Dartmoor National Park, to the north of the B3357, between Dartmeet and Two Bridges.  It is very close to the road, and beside it is the ancient Dunnabridge Pound Farm.

name: St John's Well (Tavistock)
description: Holy Well or Sacred Spring in Devon

name: Holming Beam Stone
description: This relocated cup-marked stone on Dartmoor is set into a dry-stone wall on the eastern edge of Holming Beam plantation, some 250m north of B3357, 1M north of Princetown.

name: St Leonard's Well (Sheepstor)
description: Holy Well or Sacred Spring in Devon. St Leonards Well is to be found tucked in against the outside of the west wall of the churchyard of the parish church in the village of Sheepstor.  It is sheltered by what looks like, and in fact is, a fragment of the churchs old east window, removed during Victorian restorations.

name: Leech Wells
description: The Leech Wells are a wet, oozy place in the high walled, toadflax and aubretia hung, Leech Well Lane where three springs flow into granite troughs. There are three springs - one for healing, one for good luck and one simply as a place of veneration.

name: Meacombe Cist
description: Small burial chamber near Moretonhampstead in Devon.

name: Long Stone (Lyn Down)
description: Pair of Standing Stones in Devon

name: Drizzlecombe row 1
description: Stone Row making up part of the Drizzlecombe complex on southwestern Dartmoor in Devon. This is a 150 metre long stone row running in a southwesterly direction between the cairn 1 with its ring of stones at its upper end, and the lovely longstone at its lower end. The row is unusual in that it is part single and part a double row.

name: Drizzlecombe row 3
description: Stone Row making up part of the Drizzlecombe complex on southwestern Dartmoor in Devon

name: Drizzlecombe cairn 2
description: Cairn with surrounding stone ring, making up part of the Drizzlecombe complex on southwestern Dartmoor in Devon

name: Drizzlecombe cairn 3
description: Cairn with surrounding stone ring, making up part of the Drizzlecombe complex on southwestern Dartmoor in Devon

name: Drizzlecombe
description: The complex of small stone circles, long rows, standing stones, cists and cairns located in this dramatic site is one of the most interesting in all of Europe.

name: Drizzlecombe Settlement
description: Ancient serttlements, making up part of the Drizzlecombe complex on southwestern Dartmoor in Devon.

name: Sharpitor NE
description: Double Stone Row on the northeastern slopes of Sharpitor in Devon

name: Merrivale NW
description: Cairn circle, part of the Merrivale complex on western Dartmoor, in Devon.

name: Merrivale Centre S
description: Cairn circle, part of the Merrivale complex on western Dartmoor, in Devon.

name: Merrivale Centre Row
description: Double Stone Row or Avenue, making up part of the Merrivale complex on the western slopes of Dartmoor in Devon

name: Merrivale Centre N
description: Cairn circle with central cist, part of the Merrivale complex on western Dartmoor, in Devon

name: Merrivale NE circle
description: Cairn circle, part of the Merrivale complex on western Dartmoor, in Devon.

name: Merrivale N circle
description: Cairn circle, part of the Merrivale complex on western Dartmoor, in Devon.

name: Merrivale SW row 3
description: Merrivale SW stone row 3, part of the Merrivale complex on western Dartmoor in Devon.

name: Merrivale Cists
description: Burial Chamber, part of the Merrivale complex, on western Dartmoor, Devon.

name: Drizzlecombe cairn 13
description: Cairn, Cist and Possible Stone Row making up part of the Drizzlecombe complex on southwestern Dartmoor in Devon. The cairn is about 12 m diameter and 1 metre high, and has a large cist in the middle.

name: Drizzlecombe cairn 4
description: Cairn with surrounding stone ring, making up part of the Drizzlecombe complex on southwestern Dartmoor in Devon

name: Drizzlecombe Giant's Basin
description: The Giants Basin is a large cairn making up part of the Drizzlecombe complex on southwestern Dartmoor in Devon. It is positioned just to the southeast of the main Drizzlecombe stone rows, at the position between rows 1 and 2.

name: Drizzlecombe W row
description: Possible Stone Row making up part of the Drizzlecombe complex on southwestern Dartmoor in Devon

name: Drizzlecombe row 2
description: Stone Row making up part of the Drizzlecombe complex on southwestern Dartmoor in Devon

name: Shaugh Moor row
description: Stone Row with cairn circle at the uphill end, on a small remaining piece of open moorland in amongst the china clay working spoil tips of Shaugh Moor.

name: Shaugh Moor Circle
description: At the upper end of the stone row, not much remains of the cairn, but a few stones can be identified of its surrounding circle.

name: Fernworthy circle
description: Stone Circle in Devon. Located in the middle of Forestry Commission land, this is a pleasant circle to visit on the way to Grey Wethers Stone Circle. It is 19.8 (65 feet) across, slightly flattened East to West, and contains twenty-seven stones that are graded in height from north to south, at which position the tallest is about 1.2m (4 feet).

name: Fernworthy stone row SW
description: The Fernworthy southewestern stone row, stone row 3 is in a much better state of repair, possibly because of the lack of forest being grown on top of it! The row is a double row with the stones spaced about a metre apart, running in a north south alignment, of which about 35 metres can be determined.

name: Fernworthy stone row SE
description: The Fernworthy southeastern stone row, stone row 2, is found between the cairn 4 and the circle. The row is short and of small stones, hard to tell whether it is a single row, or a double row with little space between the two rows, rather like on Harford Hill.

name: Fernworthy stone row N
description: The northern stone row, or stone row 1, is to the north of the stone circle, and found by walking to the edge of the forest clearing and taking the trackway through to the next open area.

name: Fernworthy settlement
description: Within the confines of Fernworthy Forest on eastern Dartmoor in Devon are the remains of many groups of hut circles, damaged to a greater or lesser extent by the forest growth.

name: Challacombe rows
description: A rare triple Stone Row on the northern slopes of Challacombe Down, on Dartmoor.

name: Hoccombe Hill (W)
description: Double Stone Row in Devon

name: Merrivale circle
description: An eleven-stone circle is a member of a group of several prehistoric structures: two stone circles, an avenue, a double row, a single row, a large damaged cist, standing stones and hut-circles.

name: Merrivale
description: Ceremonial Complex including two Multiple Stone Rows or Avenues, two more (at least) single stone rows, a stone circle, a large menhir (plus probably one more fallen), many burial cairns and cists, and an ancient settlement, on the western slopes of Dartmoor in Devon

name: Merrivale North Row
description: Double Stone Row making up part of the Merrivale complex on western Dartmoor in Devon

name: Merrivale settlement
description: Ancient Settlement  in Devon

name: Corringdon Ball
description: Corringdon Ball complex, southern Dartmoor, Devon SX666612

name: Corringdon Ball Central
description: Triple Stone Row almost 80m in length, which is part of the Corringdon Ball complex of stone monuments, on the flattish slopes above and to the west of the East Glaze brook, southern Dartmoor.

name: Corringdon Ball South
description: Multiple Stone Row, which is part of the Corringdon Ball complex of stone monuments, on the flattish slopes above and to the west of the East Glaze brook, southern Dartmoor.

name: Corringdon Ball N.
description: Single Stone Row, 132m in length, which is part of the Corringdon Ball complex of stone monuments, on the flattish slopes above and to the west of the East Glaze brook, southern Dartmoor.

name: Corringdon Ball Cairns
description: There are the remains of several cairns just upslope from the Corringdon Ball complex, on southern Dartmoor in Devon in Devon.

name: Corringdon Ball SE
