description: Cairn-circle at the northeastern end of the multiple stone rows, which is part of the Corringdon Ball complex of stone monuments, on the flattish slopes above and to the west of the East Glaze brook, southern Dartmoor.

name: The Round Pound
description: One of the most impressive of ancient remains to be found on the lower northwest slopes of Kestor, near Batworthy Corner, is that of The Round Pound.

name: Scorhill
description: Scorhill Stone Circle and Standing Stone on Scorhill Down, northeast Dartmoor, with it's dramatic setting on the rugged moorlands makes this 26.8m (88-foot) circle a worthwhile visit.

name: Sherberton circle
description: Sherberton Stone Circle is approximately 30 metres in diameter with only 9 slabs still remaining in its northwest quadrant.

name: Sherberton Row
description: Sherberton Double Stone Row. Location SX63927328 on Dartmoor in Devon. First recognised by Brian Byng in 1997 and now listed.

name: Down Ridge
description: Down Ridge, or Hexworthy stone circle is on sloping ground on the northeastern flank of Down Ridge above Hexworthy, just above the enclosed areas below. There is not a huge amount left, and much of that is at the uphill side. It is 25m in diameter, 9 stones remain.

name: Conies Down
description: Conies Down Double Stone Row on Dartmoor is within the Merrivale military live firing range, so it is important that you check that there is no firing and that the range is open for visitors before you set off.

name: Hamel Down row
description: Stone Row (Alignment) in Devon, Reportedly destroyed, but now back from the dead !

name: Penn Beacon SW
description: Double Stone Row on the slopes of Penn Beacon, Dartmoor, Devon

name: Penn Beacon SE
description: Stone Row on the slopes of Penn Beacon, Dartmoor, Devon

name: Shovel Down stone circle
description: The Stone Circle at the Shovel Down complex is probably the oldest of the monuments in this ceremonial centre.

name: Shovel Down row 3
description: Double Stone Row between SX65908620 and SX65948603 making up part of the Shovel Down complex of sites on eastern Dartmoor

name: Shovel Down Settlement
description: Settlement in Devon. On the upper slopes of Shovel Down, to the west of the ceremonial complex of rows, circles, cairns and menhirs, can be found the remains of an ancient settlement.

name: Black Tor SW
description: Double stone row leading from the larger cairn to be found. This row is composed entirely of small unimpressive stones and is a powerful reminder that this type of monument is often far from visually spectacular.

name: Fernworthy Cairn E
description: Fernworthy Cairn 5 can be found less than a hundred metres to the east of the stone circle up a slight raise. It is up to 10 m diameter, and has a small 5 m diameter mound in the centre, surrounded by a flatter region and remains of a ring of surrounding stones.

name: Shovel Down
description: Near the northeastern corner of Dartmoor, to the west of the old stannary town of Chagford at Shovel Down, are a multitude of remains which together make up the Shovel Down complex of ceremonial sites.

name: Nine Stones (Belstone)
description: A nice neat little stone circle on the moors below Belstone Tor on the common to the south of the village of Belstone, Devon. This circle is almost certainly the remains of a round burial cairn, and traces of the burial chamber can be seen within the circle.

name: Shovel Down Fourfold Circle
description: Known as the Fourfold circle, the larger ring encloses 3 others, the innermost only 8 feet in diameter. An avenue of stones 505 feet long and 4 feet wide (Row 2) climbs to the S up a slope to approach the circle.

name: The Longstone (Shovel Down)
description: The lovely megalith known as The Longstone stands on the eastern slopes of Shovel Down, Dartmoor, Devon, and is part of the large Shovel Down group of ceremonial monuments

name: Shovel Down row 4
description: Double Stone Row between SX65928600 and SX66008593 making up part of the Shovel Down complex of sites on eastern Dartmoor

name: Shovel Down row 5
description: Double Stone Row between SX66008585 and SX66038568 making up part of the Shovel Down complex of sites on eastern Dartmoor

name: Shovel Down row 6
description: Destroyed Double Stone Row originally making up part of the Shovel Down complex of sites on eastern Dartmoor

name: Three Boys
description: At 1.4 metres long, this fairly large, almost fallen flat stone faces across the line at the southern end of Shovel Down row 6 on Dartmoor and was probably once a blocking stone. The stone is the single survivor of what was originally three stones.

name: Shovel Down row 1
description: Much ruined single Stone Row, 500m in length, SX66008625 to SX660857, which is a part of the Shovel Down Ceremonial centre on Dartmoor, Devon

name: Shovel Down row 7
description: Destroyed Double Stone Row originally making up part of the Shovel Down complex of sites on eastern Dartmoor

name: Trowlesworthy
description: Megalithic Complex in Devon. This is the overall site entry as there are many elements in the Trowlesworthy Complex. The two cairn stone rings and avenues described in the 4 other entries for Trowlesworthy plus several settlements and cairns. It truly is a megalithic 'complex'.

name: Trowlesworthy East row
description: On the lower slopes of Trowlesworthy Tor, above the marshes surrounding the Blacka Brook, are found a couple of stone rows, one single and one double, each with its own cairn and circle of stones at their head.

name: Sharpitor cairn circle
description: Cairn Circle and cist on the slopes of Sharpitor in Devon

name: Sharpitor NW double row
description: Situated on the north western slopes of Sharpitor, just to the south of the B3212 by Goatstone Pool, can be found the remains of a fairly ruinous double stone row and a single stone row.

name: Sharpitor NW single row
description: Situated on the north western slopes of Sharpitor, just to the south of the B3212 by Goatstone Pool, can be found the remains of a fairly ruinous double stone row and a single stone row.

name: Sharpitor W
description: Situated on the western slopes of Sharpitor, to the northwest of the B3212, are the remains of a nice single stone row.

name: Leeden Tor
description: Stone Row on the slopes of Leeden Tor, Dartmoor, Devon

name: Hart Tor North circle
description: Kerbed cairn at the head of the Hart Tor, North stone row, located on the south-western slopes of Hart Tor, just across the river Meavy from Black Tor

name: Hart Tor south row
description: Single Stone row situated on the south-western slopes of Hart Tor, just across the river Meavy from Black Tor.

name: Hart Tor north rows
description: Double stone row situated on the south-western slopes of Hart Tor, just across the river Meavy from Black Tor

name: Assycombe
description: Double Stone Row in Devon

name: White Moor Down
description: A truly lovely 20 metre diameter stone circle, miles away from any signs of modern life in the middle of the desolate Dartmoor.

name: White Moor Cairn
description: Much robbed cairn, 8.5 metres in diameter, which lies approximately mid way between the White Moor Stone circle, and the outlying White Moor Stone to the southeast.

name: White Moor Stone
description: 150 metres southeast of the White Moor Stone circle stands the White Moor Stone, which is more than 5 feet in height, and has been adapted as a parish boundary stone, with its parish marks cut into it.

name: Cosdon Hill Summit Cairns
description: The remains of five widely varying cairns can be found at the summit of Cosdon Hill, north Dartmoor, Devon, approximately following the ridge of the hill in a north-south manner.

name: Cosdon Hill Multiple Stone Rows
description: On a flattish shelf of land on the eastern side of Cosdon Hill, Dartmoor,  are the splendid remains of a cairn and treble stone row.

name: Cosdon Hill Cairn Circle
description: Cosdon Hill Cairn Circle lies at the upper end of the splendid Cosdon Hill triple row on a flattish shelf of land on the eastern side of Cosdon Hill

name: The Longstone (Piles Hill)
description: This large pointy topped stone just below the summit of Piles Hill, over 2 metres in height, leans at an angle although it has been only recently re-erected. It probably marked the northern end of the Butterdon Hill stone row.

name: Copplestone Cross
description: Probably the finest Saxon cross in south-western England. Granite cross shaft of the 10th century with carved interlace ornament on each face. Carvings also show a figure on horseback and two embracing figures. The cross is mentioned in a charter of 947.

name: Bennet's Cross
description: This is a lovely cross, believed to have been carved from a prehistoric menhir. It stands about 1.7 metres tall, and is just beside the B3212 road near its high point as it crosses the moor between Moretonhampstead and Postbridge, at an altitude of about 430 metres.

name: Cornridge SE
description:
Cairn and surrounding circle, Corn Ridge, Dartmoor, Devon.       

The remains of a nice large cairn can be found at the summit of Corn Ridge, about 10m diameter.

name: Sourton Tors Stone Circle
description: Stone Circle, Sourton Tors, Dartmoor, Devon

name: Harford S.
description:
Stone Rows, Harford Moor, Dartmoor, Devon SX652599 

On Harford Moor, the southwestern slopes below Piles Hill, near to the upper reaches of Butter Brook, are the remains of a couple of stone alignments, which are very close together.

name: Harford Moor N
description: Stone Rows, Harford Moor, Dartmoor, Devon SX652599. On Harford Moor, the southwestern slopes below Piles Hill, near to the upper reaches of Butter Brook, are the remains of a couple of stone alignments, which are very close together.

name: Butterbrook
description: Butterbrook Stone Rows, Harford Moor, Dartmoor, Devon SX652599

name: Cantrell
description: Cantrell Double Stone Row @ SX 6570 5717 has a cairn at the upper end which is on the skyline when viewed from the lower end of the row. The ruined cairn is 8m diameter & has a single slab at the centre in a hollow. Perhaps the remains of a burial kist.

name: Butterdon Stone Circle
description: The remains of the fantastic Butterdon Hill stone row run for nearly 2 kilometres across the moor in a roughly northerly direction from Butterdon Hill. The row starts at a cairn, which is situated just downslope to the north of the largest cairn on the hilltop.

name: Butterdon Hill Row
description: The second second longest on the moor. Single row 2000 metres long. Azimuth 2 variable. The row run runs along a high plateau almost North - South and starting from the southern end has a large terminal cairn surrounded by a circle of stones.

name: Glasscombe Ball North
description: The remains of this row can be found at the top of the ridge on the saddle between Glasscombe Ball and Piles Hill just to the east of the old tramway.

name: Glasscombe Corner Stone Row
description: On the eastern slopes of Piles Hill / Glasscombe Ball, just above Glasscombe Corner, is the remains of this combination double and single row of stones, about 180m long. The single section, which comprises the NE one-third of the total length, consists of slightly taller stones.

name: Glasscombe Ball NE
description: Glasscombe Stone Row Terminal Cairn (NE end). Also see

name: Hobajons Cross
description: Standing Stone with cross in Devon. This relatively large stone is part of the Butterdon Hill row, and has a simple cross carved into it on the western face.

name: Spurrells Cross Cairn Circle
description: Spurrells Cross Cairn Circle, Butterdon Hill, Dartmoor, Devon.

name: Butterdon Hill Barrow
description: Round Barrow on Butterdon Hill, Dartmoor, Devon, associated with nearby stone row.

name: Hook Lake Row
description: Remains of a double stone row which can be found on the eastern banks of the upper Erme valley in the middle of deepest southern Dartmoor.

name: Longstone (Challacombe)
description: Three kilometres from the nearest road and standing almost 3 metres high, the Longstone at Challacombe is the tallest stone on Exmoor.

name: Longstone Barrow Row
description: My notes for this say that there should be three stones in a row, with nowadays possibly one of them missing.

name: Great Links Tor Cairn
description: The remains of a large cairn can be found on the southwest slopes of Great Links Tor, about 15m diameter.

name: Gidleigh Chambered Cairn
description: A ruinous chambered cairn on the eastern side of Buttern Hill, west of Gidleigh village.

name: Piles Hill Cairns
description: Cairns in Devon

name: Sourton Tors Ring Cairns
description: Ring Cairns in Devon. The remains of two ring cairns can be seen on the slopes of Sourton Tors, just below the track which continues along from the remains of the tramway beyond the points, at which the railway reversed, the southernmost being slightly larger.

name: Sourton Tors Cairn
description: Cairn in Devon. The remains of a much destroyed cairn can be seen on the slopes of Corn Ridge, just above the track which passes up over the saddle between Sourton Tors and Corn Ridge.

name: Lundy Beacon Hill
description: Early Christian Sculptured Stone in Devon.

name: Lundy John O'Groats
description: Round Barrow in Devon

name: Lundy Barrow
description: Round Barrow  in Devon.

name: Lundy Settlement
description: At the extreme north end of Lundy Island is a prehistoric settlement believed to date from around 1000 BC.

name: Butterdon Hill Cairns
description: Cairns in Devon. At the summit of Butterdon Hill are two very large cairns, with others to be seen in the vicinity.

name: Spurrells Cross Row
description: Multiple Stone Rows or Avenue with terminal cairn in Devon

name: Woodbarrow Stone Setting
description: Out on the wet blowy moorland slopes of Exmoor to the south below Woodbarrow, is to be found a stone setting. Although I was not exactly sure what I was looking for, my notes said it was a double row.

name: Hurston Ridge
description: This fine double stone row lies approximatly NE/SW on a ridge at the south end of Chagford Common. It is best reached by parking near the Warren House Inn and walking up Water Hill, then follow the reave in a North Westerly direction.

name: Piles Hill W
description: This wonderful monument consists of an avenue of large stones, almost a kilometre in length running in an west to east direction over the top of the ridge of Piles Hill. The stones are generally between 1 and 2 metres in length, with many more than 2 metres.

name: Piles Hill NE
description: This wonderful monument consists of an avenue of large stones, almost a kilometre in length running in an west to east direction over the top of the ridge of Piles Hill. The stones are generally between 1 and 2 metres in length, with many more than 2 metres. The western end is at SX65056111 the eastern end at SX65886111

name: Corringdon Ball Tomb
description: The remains of Corringdon Ball chambered tomb are marked on the map as Long Barrow, and it is situated on the saddle of land between Corringdon Ball and Brent Fore Hill, not far from the cairn at the head of the Brent Fore row.

name: Oxenham Arms
description: An enormous and magnificent menhir built into the wall of a tremendous pub on the main street in the village of South Zeal, Devon. In fact, the pub is believed to have been built by monks in the twelfth century around the menhir.

name: Lidwell
description: This lonely spot is home to the remains of a small 13th century chapel. Although neatly fenced it is almost impossible to visit without Wellington boots as the whole area is running with water some of which flows from the well which is just on the right inside the iron fence. It used to be in a corner of the chapel before it became a ruin.

name: St Nectan's Well (Stoke)
description: Holy Well in Devon. St Nectans Well is on the site of the hut where the 6th century Welsh hermit, St Nectan, is said to have returned carrying his head after being set upon by thieves who beheaded him.

name: Beaples Hill
description: The Three Cornered Longstone is located at Beaples hill adjacent to the Tiverton to Barnstable link road. The bronze age Standing Stone remnant, lies SW of Knowstone Inner Moor & its Bronze age barrows.

name: Broadsands Chambered Tomb
description: A Neolithic chambered tomb or passage grave located on the southern slope overlooking Torbay coast at Broadsands. This megalithic chamber has a single parallel-sided entrance passage 3.8 metres long and 1.2 metres wide lined with alternating orthostats and dry stone walling set within a near circular cairn 12 metres in diameter at construction but later reduced to 7 metres north east by 9 metres east west.

name: Boringdon Camp
description: Hillfort in Devon

name: Brent Hill
description: Hillfort in Devon

name: Castle Dyke (Chudleigh)
description: Hillfort in Devon

name: Hunter's Tor Fort
description: Hillfort in Devon

name: Mattocks Down Barrow
description: Long Barrow in Devon

name: Mattocks Down Stone
description: 2.5 metre tall Standing Stone near to Mattocks Down, which was fairly recently damaged by a lightning strike. There are four barrows nearby.

name: Raddon Hill
description: Causewayed Enclosure in Devon

name: Wooston Castle
description: Hillfort in Devon

name: Five Barrows (Devon)
description: Five Barrows cemetery actually consists of nine barrows, one of which is a Bell barrow.

name: Yelland
description: Double Stone Row in Devon

name: Buttern E
description: Buttern Stone Circle, SX 6494 8848, on the western slopes of Buttern Hill, northeast Dartmoor.

name: Kentisbury Down
description: SE from Combe Martin, along the A399, west of Parracombe, lie a group of standing stones. Off the A399, turn right onto Down Lane, which has a broad green strip up the middle for as far as you can see. We parked in front of gate, (a wind pump should be to your front left) to allow for space for other vehicles; however, we were there some 40 minutes (Helen remaining in the car), and did not see one other vehicle!

name: Damage Barton
description: Just a little to the west of Ilfracombe, lie 3 standing stones in close proximity to each other. Go west through the town centre, where the A399 becomes the A361. After a Church and Cemetery on your right on a bend, you will need to take a very sudden right hand turn towards Lee. One point of possible interest along the way, is a place called 'Whitestone', which is marked on the map. Around grid reference 497462, we saw an enormous white stone to the right of the road, before we descended a hill and it became obscured by a hedge. The stone was not marked on the map, but it looked a clear contender for a place worth looking at, access permitting.

name: Knap Down
description: Standing Stone in Devon

name: Yar Tor SE
description: Much ruined triple stone row on the southeastern slopes of Yar Tor near Dartmeet in Devon

name: Trendlebere Down Stone Row Cairn
description: Cairn in Devon, associated with nearby stone row.

name: Ringmoor Down stone circle
description: On the top of the open moor that is Ringmoor Down, to the north of Brisworthy and its stone circle, this tremendous cairn circle and associated stone row are to be found, although they were "restored" in 1909, supposedly not very accurately.

name: Yellowmead row
description: Possible Multiple Stone Row in Devon

name: Spinsters' Rock
description: Burial Chamber (Dolmen) in Devon. The burial chamber is composed of a large capstone supported on three uprights.  The tomb collapsed in 1858 and was reconstructed soon afterwards, but not exactly as it had been originally.

name: Lower Piles
description: Cairn  with retaining kerb and with cist in Devon

name: Trowlesworthy East circle
description: On the lower slopes of Trowlesworthy Tor, above the marshes surrounding the Blacka Brook, are found a couple of stone rows, one single and one double, each with its own cairn and circle of stones at their head.

name: White Ridge
description: This stone row is 167m long, descending the hill from a ruined 8m diameter cairn [at SX65418165; 50.618984, -3.9039010]. 41 stones still show. The cairn is on the skyline when viewed from the bottom of the row.

name: Lakehead Hill 5
description: Cairn Circle on Lakehead Hill, near Postbridge, Dartmoor. One of several ancient sites on Lakehead Hill.

name: Burford Down Cairn Circle
description: Cairn Circle in Devon

name: Buckland Ford
description: Cairn Circle on remote southern Dartmoor near to Buckland Ford.

name: Brown Heath Cairn and Cist
description: This encircled cairn and cist is featured on the Prehistoric Dartmoor Walks (PDW) website - see their entry for the

name: Brockhill Ford
description: Cairn circle with cist.

name: Three Barrows (Devon)
description: Barrow Cemetery in Devon

name: Shoulsbury Castle
description: Hillfort in Devon

name: Setta Barrow
description: Round Barrow in Devon

name: Lakehead Cairn Circle 1
description: Cairn Circle with central cist on Lakehead Hill, central Dartmoor, in Devon

name: Lakehead Hill 2
description: A fairly large cist box standing proud of the ground oat the western side of Lakehead Hill, at the edge of the forest. There is nothing too obvious of a cairn or circle surrounding it.

name: Huccaby Rings Inner
description: Ancient Hillslope Enclosure in Devon

name: Huccaby Rings Outer
description: Ancient Hillslope Enclosure in Devon

name: Halwell Camp North East
description: Hillfort in Devon

name: Halwell Camp South West
description: Hillfort in Devon

name: Farway & Gittisham Hill Cemetery
description: Barrow Cemetery of around thirty-three round barrows in Devon

name: Cranbrook Castle
description: Hillfort in Devon

name: Clovelly Dykes
description: Multiple-Enclosure Hillfort in Devon

name: Chapman Barrows
description: There are about half a dozen large round barrows in an east to west line running up the western slope and over the top of Chapman Down, and with a few other barrows also scattered about nearby making a total of eleven barrows in all.

name: Beardown Man
description: Standing Stone on Devil's Tor near the head of the Cowsic River, out in the midst of Dartmoor.

name: Furzehill Common 1
description: On the western slopes of Furzehill Common ridge, I first found a large boulder like stone, and with some further searching around, I found a sort of line of stones running down the side of the hill. I found two stones high up the slope which are spaced at about 10 metres from each other, (the uppermost fallen), and two more further down the slope, one of which is a nice stander.

name: Furzehill Common stone row
description: Here I found four little stumps of stone in a row, in a boggy hollow on top of the ridge. They are spaced 2.5, 5, 2.5 metres apart, suggesting a missing stone in between those I could find.

name: Hoccombe Coombe
description: A Multiple Stone Row in Devon, oncle thought to be a stone circle.

name: Cheriton Ridge 4
description: South along the Two Moors Way (Tarka Trail) along the top of the Cheriton Ridge, and a couple of kilometres out onto the open moorland can be found the remains of this stone setting.

name: Cheriton Ridge 2
description: South along the Two Moors Way (Tarka Trail) along the top of the Cheriton Ridge, and a couple of kilometres out onto the open moorland can be found the remains of this stone setting.

name: Yar Tor NW
description: Much ruined triple stone row on the southeastern slopes of Yar Tor near Dartmeet in Devon

name: Joan Ford Newtake row
description: Three slabs stand in a row on the slopes to the northwest of the Swincombe waterworks lake.

name: Thornworthy Little Common
description: Stone Row on the slopes of the Thornworthy valley on Exmoor.

name: Cheriton Ridge stone row
description: South along the Two Moors Way (Tarka Trail) along the top of the Cheriton Ridge, and a couple of kilometres out onto the open moorland can be found the small remains of this stone row.

name: Oke Tor
description: Stone Row (Alignment) in Devon

name: Lakehead Hill
description: This site page serves as the main page for complex Lakehead Hill area, as it has a number of ancient monuments within a small area. If you look below, you will see photographs for each of the different sites in this vicinity. Each of the individual sites has its own separate site pages with more information, and for you to submit photographs and visit reports to - see the 'nearby sites' list below.

name: Lakehead Hill W
description: A single stone row, orientated east - west, lies just to the north of the summit of Lakehead Hill on Dartmoor in Devon.

name: Lakehead Hill E
description: A short stone row leads up a circle of stones surrounding a covered kist. The row has suffered the fate of being excavated and 'restored' in 1895 by the Dartmoor Exploration Committee, so many of the features seen today are unlikely to have been original. Yet the kink in the row as it approaches the circle is similar to many other rows on the moors. There were no finds recovered.

name: Down Tor stone row
description: Down Tor (Hingston Hill) stone row, SX 5902 6939 to SX 5868 6927.

name: Collard Tor W
description: A pair of single stone rows each leading downslope (south) from a separate cairn. The rows lead through an area of clutter making them difficult to define in places.

name: Collard Tor E
description: A pair of single stone rows each leading downslope (south) from a separate cairn. The rows lead through an area of clutter making them difficult to define in places.

name: Cholwichtown stone row
description: There was once a 217 metre long single Stone Row here with 91 remaining large stones, before it was excavated in 1961 before total destruction as part of the china clay works. Only the rows on

name: Burford Down Stone Row
description: Stone Row in Devon with cairn circle: one of the finest in Dartmoor, shows evidence of recent damage by whatever farmer is running huge tractors across the fields.

name: Woodbarrow Hangings
description: Stone setting to the north of Woodbarrow on Exmoor, just inside the Devon side of the border.

name: Winnaway
description: Stone setting on the northern slopes below The Chains of Exmoor with 4 remaining stones.

name: White Ladder
description:
Double Stone Row in Devon. During 2006 the particularly dry conditions have caused peat shrinkage and this has in turn led
to the re-emergence of the Whiteladder Stone Row on Five Barrows Hill, first discovered by Hazel Eardley-Wilmot in
1975. At least 4 pairs of stones not visible in May 2006 had emerged by the end of the summer, confirming that
Whiteladder is a double stone row of local slate and lumps of white quartz.

name: Hoaroak 1
description: This is a nice little setting of stones, mostly on open grassland, making it easy to see and find! I found six little stones in a D shape, with two or three more downhill from them, plus a few more stones scattered about seemingly randomly.

name: Higher White Tor stone row
description: Remains of a double stone row to the south of Higher White Tor on Dartmoor

name: Laughter Tor row 1
description: A large standing stone and remains of two double stone rows can be found here on Laughter Tor.

name: Trendlebere Down
description: Double Stone Row in Devon. The approach to the stone row is down a slope from the road, under Black Hill. Apparently an associated cairn was situated 10m north of the road, and is "barely recognizable, merely a low crescent of earth with a few stones embedded in the turf." [Butler].

name: Trowlesworthy West row
description: On the lower slopes of Trowlesworthy Tor, above the marshes surrounding the Blacka Brook, are found a couple of stone rows, one single and one double, each with its own cairn and circle of stones at their head.

name: Ringmoor Down Stone Row
description: On the top of the open moor that is Ringmoor Down, to the north of Brisworthy and its stone circle, this tremendous cairn circle and 369m long stone row are to be found, although they were "restored" in 1909, supposedly not very accurately, and as a result little is known as to its original length or format.

name: Mardle Embanked Cairn
description: Ancient site in Devon

name: Joan Ford Newtake W
description: Joan Ford Newtake W, a little cairn or stone circle at the corner of the enclosure wall with its gated entrance.

name: Harford Moor Encircled Cairn
description: Cairn in Devon

name: Cholwich Town Cairn Circle
description: Stone Circle in Devon

name: Buttern W
description: In the late nineteenth century, Worth reported a second stone circle, about 20 metres in diameter, a short distance from Buttern Hill circle, on the slope to the westward, with 4 or 5 stones standing.

name: Larkbarrow Corner Standing Stone
description: Standing Stone in Devon

name: Deadman's Bottom Cists
description: Two cisted grave cairns, All elements of the two cisted graves appear to be present, The Southern cist has a cairn circle around it, The Northern cist is on the edge of a cairn. At the East and West of the cists are small enclosures.

name: Larkbarrow Corner Stone Setting
description: A square shaped setting (fourth stone broken off at ground level) with a flat stone in the middle.

name: Stalldown Cairn Circle
description: This small circle lies adjacent to the impressive Stalldown row, and indeed two of the outer stones are more appropriate to the row alignment. One of these stones lies flat, while the other is a pointed pillar aligned with the row.

name: Trowlesworthy West circle
description: On the lower slopes of Trowlesworthy Tor, above the marshes surrounding the Blacka Brook, are found a couple of stone rows, one single and one double, each with its own cairn and circle of stones at their head.

name: Wigford Down 1
description: Adjacent ring-cairns in Devon

name: Harbourne Head B
description: Embanked Cairn Circle / Stone Circle in Devon

name: Joan Ford Newtake E
description: Remains of a well defined circular cairn, with a clear 8 metre diameter kerb of stones around the outside. Centrally is a large cist of which all four side slabs remain, as well as the displaced capstone.

name: Mardon Down S
description: Mardon Down Stone Circle is the largest on Dartmoor at 38 metres diameter and nowadays clear to see but in a very ruinous state, with only 2 or 3 stones still standing of what was probably once between 60 and 70.

name: Bellever Tor 2
description: This encircled cairn is recorded as

name: Seven Stones (Devon)
description: Site of what was believed to be a bronze age Stone Circle, which was dug up and removed to become a garden feature in 1830.

name: Yardworthy
description: Stone Row (Alignment) in Devon

name: Treeland Brake
description: Treeland Brake stone row was destroyed by agricultural activity in 1977.
